contextId.information: These idioms mean the same thing and emphasize how much the Esther pleased the king. AT: "greatly pleased him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: received acceptance and favor before him

contextId.information: Here "seat of authority" represents his position or status in the government. AT: "promoted him above the other officials" or "gave him more authority than all the other officials" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: placed his seat of authority above all the officials who were with him

contextId.information: This idiom means they personally delivered the letters. AT: "personally delivered" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

"Find favor" is an idiom that means to be approved of or that he is pleased with her. "In your eyes" is a metaphor representing his evaluation. AT: "If you evaluate me and approve" or "If you are pleased with me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: If I have found favor in your eyes, king

contextId.information: To fill one's heart to do something is an idiom meaning to dare to do something. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Where is the one who has dared to so such a thing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Where is this person to be found who has filled his heart to do such a thing

contextId.information: Being in a rage is an idiom for being extremely angry. AT: "The king was extremely angry and got up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: The king got up in a rage

contextId.information: "Find favor" is an idiom that means be approved of or that he is pleased with her. "In your sight" is a metaphor representing his evaluation. AT: "if you evaluate me and approve" or "if you are pleased with me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: if I have found favor in your sight

contextId.information: "To take vengeance on people" is an idiom meaning to hurt people who have hurt you. AT: "to fight back against their enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: to take vengeance on their enemies

contextId.information: "Carry out" is an idiom meaning to do something that was commanded or planned. This can be stated in active form. AT: "when the people were about to obey the king's law and decree" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: when the king's law and decree were about to be carried out

contextId.information: To bring disaster on people is an idiom meaning to cause a disaster to happen to them. In this case it refers to destroying them. AT: "who tried to destroy them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: who tried to bring disaster on them
